content.title: Transmetatarsal Amputation
content.description: Partial foot amputation through the metatarsal bones, preserving heel and midfoot for ambulation without need for prosthesis.
content.definition: Transmetatarsal amputation (TMA) removes all toes and metatarsal heads while preserving the heel, midfoot, and ankle. When successful, patients can ambulate with a shoe filler rather than a prosthesis, maintaining near-normal gait with minimal energy expenditure increase.

surgical_technique: Plantar flap longer than dorsal (well-vascularized sole skin)
All metatarsals at same level to prevent pressure points
Preserve as much plantar tissue as possible
May require tendon balancing to prevent equinus
healing_requirements: ABI typically >0.5 or toe pressure >30 mmHg
healing_rates: Higher failure rate than major amputation
Diabetics at higher risk for complications
functional_outcomes: May need Achilles lengthening to prevent equinus

clinical_pearls: TMA success depends on viable plantar skin for flap
Equinus deformity from unopposed plantarflexion is common
Prophylactic Achilles lengthening reduces equinus risk
Higher failure rate but excellent function when healed
Shoe filler and rocker-bottom shoe optimize gait
